character.appearance: Scary Illidan-looking Antler Devil. Purple/Red/Pink/Orange dusk-colored skin, gnarled and scarred

backgroundlink.recordname: reference.backgrounddata.fartraveler@D&D Sword Coast Adventurer's Guide - Player's Guide

character.bonds:
I owe my life to the priest who took me in when my parents died.

Though I had no choice, I lament having to leave my loved one(s) behind. I hope to see them again one day.

So long as I have this token from my homeland, I can face any adversity in this strange land.

I entered seclusion to hide from the ones who might still be hunting me. I must someday confront them.

I'm still seeking the enlightenment I pursued in my seclusion, and it still eludes me.

shortcut.recordname: reference.classdata.monk@D&D Sword Coast Adventurer's Guide - Player's Guide

text.p: Your accent, mannerisms, figures of speech, and perhaps even your appearance all mark you as foreign. Curious glances are directed your way wherever you go, which can be a nuisance, but you also gain the friendly interest of scholars and others intrigued by far-off lands, to say nothing of everyday folk who are eager to hear stories of your homeland.

You can parley this attention into access to people and places you might not otherwise have, for you and your traveling companions. Noble lords, scholars, and merchant princes, to name a few, might be interested in hearing about your distant homeland and people.
Beginning at 1st level, while you are wearing no armor and not wielding a shield, your AC equals 10 + your Dexterity modifier + your Wisdom modifier.

At 1st level, your practice of martial arts gives you mastery of combat styles that use unarmed strikes and monk weapons, which are shortswords and any simple melee weapons that don't have the two-handed or heavy property.
You gain the following benefits while you are unarmed or wielding only monk weapons and you aren't wearing armor or wielding a shield:

list.li: You can use Dexterity instead of Strength for the attack and damage rolls of your unarmed strikes and monk weapons.
You can roll a d4 in place of the normal damage of your unarmed strike or monk weapon. This die changes as you gain monk levels, as shown in the Martial Arts column of the Monk table.

When you use the Attack action with an unarmed strike or a monk weapon on your turn, you can make one unarmed strike as a bonus action. For example, if you take the Attack action and attack with a quarterstaff, you can also make an unarmed strike as a bonus action, assuming you haven't already taken a bonus action this turn.

text.p: Certain monasteries use specialized forms of the monk weapons. For example, you might use a club that is two lengths of wood connected by a short chain (called a nunchaku) or a sickle with a shorter, straighter blade (called a kama). Whatever name you use for a monk weapon, you can use the game statistics provided for the weapon in chapter 5.
Starting at 2nd level, your speed increases by 10 feet while you are not wearing armor or wielding a shield. This bonus increases when you reach certain monk levels, as shown in the Monk table.
At 9th level, you gain the ability to move along vertical surfaces and across liquids on your turn without falling during the move.

Starting at 2nd level, your training allows you to harness the mystic energy of ki. Your access to this energy is represented by a number of ki points. Your monk level determines the number of points you have, as shown in the Ki Points column of the Monk table. You can spend these points to fuel various ki features. You start knowing three such features: Flurry of Blows, Patient Defense, and Step of the Wind. You learn more ki features as you gain levels in this class. When you spend a ki point, it is unavailable until you finish a short or long rest, at the end of which you draw all of your expended ki back into yourself. You must spend at least 30 minutes of the rest meditating to regain your ki points.
Some of your ki features require your target to make a saving throw to resist the feature's effects. The saving throw DC is calculated as follows:
Ki save DC = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Wisdom modifier
Immediately after you take the Attack action on your turn, you can spend 1 ki point to make two unarmed strikes as a bonus action.
You can spend 1 ki point to take the Dodge action as a bonus action on your turn.
You can spend 1 ki point to take the Disengage or Dash action as a bonus action on your turn, and your jump distance is doubled for the turn.

Monks of the Way of the Sun Soul learn to channel their own life energy into searing bolts of light. They teach that meditation can unlock the ability to unleash the indomitable light shed by the soul of every living creature.

link.recordname: reference.classdata.monk.features.radiantsunbolt3@D&D Sword Coast Adventurer's Guide - Player's Guide
reference.classdata.monk.features.searingarcstrike6@D&D Sword Coast Adventurer's Guide - Player's Guide
reference.classdata.monk.features.searingsunburst11@D&D Sword Coast Adventurer's Guide - Player's Guide
reference.classdata.monk.features.sunshield17@D&D Sword Coast Adventurer's Guide - Player's Guide

text.p: Starting when you choose this tradition at 3rd level, you can hurl searing bolts of magical radiance.

You gain a ranged spell attack that you can use with the Attack action. The attack has a range of 30 feet. You are proficient with it, and you add your Dexterity modifier to its attack and damage rolls. Its damage is radiant, and its damage die is a d4. This die changes as you gain monk levels, as shown in the Martial Arts column of the Monk table.
When you use the Attack action on your turn to use this special attack, you can spend 1 ki point to make two additional attacks with it as a bonus action.

Starting at 3rd level, you can use your reaction to deflect or catch the missile when you are hit by a ranged weapon attack (20/60 ft.). When you do so, the damage you take from the attack is reduced by 1d10 + your Dexterity modifier + your monk level.

If you reduce the damage to 0, you can catch the missile if it is small enough for you to hold in one hand and you have at least one hand free. If you catch a missile in this way, you can spend 1 ki point to make a ranged attack with the weapon or piece of ammunition you just caught, as part of the same reaction. You make this attack with proficiency, regardless of your weapon proficiencies, and the missile counts as a monk weapon for the attack.
Beginning at 4th level, you can use your reaction when you fall to reduce any falling damage you take by an amount equal to five times your monk level.

When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

character.flaws:
I've spent so long in the temple that I have little practical experience dealing with people in the outside world.

I am suspicious of strangers and expect the worst of them. I am slow to trust members of other races, tribes, and societies.

I judge others harshly, and myself even more severely.

I harbor dark, bloodthirsty thoughts that my isolation and meditation failed to quell.

Violence is my answer to almost any challenge.
character.ideals:
Aspiration. I seek to prove myself worthy of my god's favor by matching my actions against his or her teachings. (Any)

Faith. I trust that my deity will guide my actions. I have faith that if I work hard, things will go well. (Lawful)

Tradition. The ancient traditions of worship and sacrifice must be preserved and upheld. (Lawful)

Suspicious. I must be careful, for I have no way of telling friend from foe here. (Any)

Change. Life is like the seasons, in constant change, and we must change with it. (Chaotic)

Glory. I must earn glory in battle, for myself and my clan. (Any)

description.p: A holy symbol is a representation of a god or pantheon. It might be an amulet depicting a symbol representing a deity, the same symbol carefully engraved or inlaid as an emblem on a shield, or a tiny box holding a fragment of a sacred relic. The Player's Handbook lists many gods in the multiverse and their typical symbols. A cleric or paladin can use a holy symbol as a spellcasting focus, as described in chapter 10. To use the symbol in this way, the caster must hold it in hand, wear it visibly, or bear it on a shield.
Rations consist of dry foods suitable for extended travel, including jerky, dried fruit, hardtack, and nuts.
A torch burns for 1 hour, providing bright light in a 20-foot radius and dim light for an additional 20 feet. If you make a melee attack with a burning torch and hit, it deals 1 fire damage.
This tin box contains a cup and simple cutlery. The box clamps together, and one side can be used as a cooking pan and the other as a plate or shallow bowl.
Rope, whether made of hemp or silk, has 2 hit points and can be burst with a DC 17 Strength check.
A ferocious-looking wooden mask

Adventuring is a hard life. With a cook along on the journey, your meals will be much better than the typical mix of hardtack and dried fruit. Cook's utensils include a metal pot, knives, forks, a stirring spoon, and a ladle.
A quiver can hold up to 20 arrows.
3 bronze singing bowls, a carved mallet, and a small windchime.
You regain 4d4 + 4 hit points when you drink this potion. The potion's red liquid glimmers when agitated.

id-00030.name: Potion of Greater Healing
id-00030.nonidentified: A vial of red liquid that shimmers when agitated.

description.p: You regain hit points when you drink this potion.
The number of hit points depends on the potion's rarity, as shown in the Potions of Healing table. Whatever its potency, the potion's red liquid glimmers when agitated.

id-00031.name: Potion of Healing
id-00031.nonidentified: The potion's red liquid glimmers when agitated.

description.p: The flame of the candle of the deep is not extinguished when immersed in water. It gives off light and heat like a normal candle.
For 1 hour, a candle sheds bright light in a 5-foot radius and dim light for an additional 5 feet.

Calligraphy treats writing as a delicate, beautiful art. Calligraphers produce text that is pleasing to the eye, using a style that is difficult to forge. Their supplies also give them some ability to examine scripts and determine if they are legitimate, since a calligrapher's training involves long hours of studying writing and attempting to replicate its style and design. Calligrapher's supplies include ink, a dozen sheets of parchment, and three quills.

While you wear this cloak with its hood up, Wisdom (Perception) checks made to see you have disadvantage, and you have advantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks made to hide, as the cloak's color shifts to camouflage you. Pulling the hood up or down requires an action.

A cloth or leather pouch can hold up to 20 sling bullets or 50 blowgun needles, among other things. A compartmentalized pouch for holding spell components is called a component pouch (described earlier in this section).
You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

You can use an action to cause thick, black poison to coat the blade. The poison remains for 1 minute or until an attack using this weapon hits a creature. That creature must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or take 2d10 poison damage and become poisoned for 1 minute. The dagger can't be used this way again until the next dawn.

id-00038.name: Dagger of Venom
id-00038.nonidentified: With a curved, exceedingly sharp, blade and a jewelled pommel this is no ordinary dagger.

description.p: When you drink this potion, you gain the effect of the clairvoyance spell. An eyeball bobs in this yellowish liquid but vanishes when the potion is opened.

id-00039.name: Potion of Clairvoyance
id-00039.nonidentified: An eyeball bobs in this yellowish liquid but vanishes when the potion is opened.

description.p: This concoction looks, smells, and tastes like a potion of healing or other beneficial potion. However, it is actually poison masked by illusion magic. An identify spell reveals its true nature.

If you drink it, you take 3d6 poison damage, and you must succeed on a DC 13 Constitution saving throw or be poisoned. At the start of each of your turns while you are poisoned in this way, you take 3d6 poison damage.
At the end of each of your turns, you can repeat the saving throw. On a successful save, the poison damage you take on your subsequent turns decreases by 1d6.
The poison ends when the damage decreases to 0.

id-00040.name: Potion of Poison
id-00040.nonidentified: The contents of this vial looks, smells and tastes like a potion of healing.

character.name: Epitaph
character.notes: Orphaned on the night of his birth. Carried to (city or towm) by his sister, Hope (Sperae). Raised as an urchin until 5, then chased from city by litch-mob. Survived in northern wilderness alone for a few weeks. Captured by Orcs. Rescued by Aarakocra Druid/Monk. Becomes diciple of Aarakocra Druid/Monk (Greyfeather). Spends some time training/studying in Feywild w/ Eladrin (Mithrendane, Autum City, Monks of the Citidel Arcanum). Elf Monks find him unworthy. Returns to Greyfeather to protect the Feywild Portal from undead. Undead horde attacks, Master dies, Vicious is only survivor. Elf Monks close the portal. Vicious heads south to look for his sister and make a life for himself.
character.personalitytraits:
I see omens in every event and action. The gods try to speak to us, we just need to listen

I begin or end my day with small traditional rituals that are unfamiliar to those around me.

I do my best to discourage anyone from approaching or talking to me.

I feel tremendous empathy for all who suffer.

I've been isolated for so long that I rarely speak, preferring gestures and the occasional grunt.

Like a wild animal, I lash out viciously when I'm provoked

Like roots growing through stone, I am relentless and determined in my action.

I connect everything that happens to me to a grand, cosmic plan.

description.p: You have resistance to fire damage.
You have bat-like wings sprouting from your shoulder blades. You have a flying speed of 30 feet. This trait replaces the Infernal Legacy trait.

Starting at 2nd level, your training allows you to harness the mystic energy of ki. Your access to this energy is represented by a number of ki points. Your monk level determines the number of points you have, as shown in the Ki Points column of the Monk table. You can spend these points to fuel various ki features. You start knowing three such features: Flurry of Blows, Patient Defense, and Step of the Wind. You learn more ki features as you gain levels in this class. When you spend a ki point, it is unavailable until you finish a short or long rest, at the end of which you draw all of your expended ki back into yourself. You must spend at least 30 minutes of the rest meditating to regain your ki points.
Some of your ki features require your target to make a saving throw to resist the feature's effects. The saving throw DC is calculated as follows:
Ki save DC = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Wisdom modifier
Immediately after you take the Attack action on your turn, you can spend 1 ki point to make two unarmed strikes as a bonus action.
You can spend 1 ki point to take the Dodge action as a bonus action on your turn.
You can spend 1 ki point to take the Disengage or Dash action as a bonus action on your turn, and your jump distance is doubled for the turn.

Starting at 3rd level, you can use your reaction to deflect or catch the missile when you are hit by a ranged weapon attack (20/60 ft.). When you do so, the damage you take from the attack is reduced by 1d10 + your Dexterity modifier + your monk level.

If you reduce the damage to 0, you can catch the missile if it is small enough for you to hold in one hand and you have at least one hand free. If you catch a missile in this way, you can spend 1 ki point to make a ranged attack with the weapon or piece of ammunition you just caught, as part of the same reaction. You make this attack with proficiency, regardless of your weapon proficiencies, and the missile counts as a monk weapon for the attack.
Starting when you choose this tradition at 3rd level, you can hurl searing bolts of magical radiance.

You gain a ranged spell attack that you can use with the Attack action. The attack has a range of 30 feet. You are proficient with it, and you add your Dexterity modifier to its attack and damage rolls. Its damage is radiant, and its damage die is a d4. This die changes as you gain monk levels, as shown in the Martial Arts column of the Monk table.
When you use the Attack action on your turn to use this special attack, you can spend 1 ki point to make two additional attacks with it as a bonus action.
You can spend 1 ki point to take the Dodge action as a bonus action on your turn.

id-00001.label: Step of the Wind; Jump doubled

description.p: You can spend 1 ki point to take the Disengage or Dash action as a bonus action on your turn, and your jump distance is doubled for the turn.

id-00001.name: Tool: Chimes. Bells. and Singing Bowls

You have bat-like wings sprouting from your shoulder blades. You have a flying speed of 30 feet. This trait replaces the Infernal Legacy trait.
